questions.text: A farmer was rushed to the emergency after sustaining a sting on his right calf. The patient is conscious and oriented with stable vitals. On local examination of the wound, there is a hole in the center of a reddened area along with edema, pain, and reddening of the limb. There is no history of nausea, vomiting, or seizures. The agent responsible for the sting is shown below. Which of the following snakebites is similar to this organism's sting?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with the image showing a scorpion points to a scorpion sting. The clinical findings of edema and pain of the limb with no neurological symptoms are consistent with hemolytic venom which is similar to that of Russel's viper.

Scorpions are eight-legged arthropods that have a hollow sting in the last joint of their tail, which secretes poison on stinging. The venom is a clear, colorless toxalbumen and is generally classified as either hemolytic or neurotoxic. 

The venom causes autonomic stimulation resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It also has a direct effect on the myocardium.

It can present as neurotoxicity with nausea, vomiting, extreme restlessness, fever, various types of paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, convulsions, coma and cyanosis, respiratory depression, and death that occurs as a result of pulmonary edema or cardiac failure. This is similar to that of a cobra bite.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom it mimics a viper bite where the reaction is mainly local, with edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours. 

Diagnosis is confirmed with ELISA.

Treatment:

  • The limb involved is immobilized and a tourniquet is secured above the level of sting. 
  • The sting is packed in ice and the wound is washed with a weak solution of ammonia, borax, or potassium permanganate after incision and suction
  • Local anesthetics may be used for pain relief
  • Specific antivenin is administered if species are identified.
  • Local swelling is controlled with the use of calcium gluconate
  • Restlessness and seizures are controlled with the use of barbiturates. The use of morphine is contraindicated.
  • Atropine is used for the prevention of pulmonary edema.
  • Prazosin can counteract the alpha-adrenergic effects of autonomic stimulation, such as hypertension

Other options :

Options A and D - The king cobra and the common krait have a venom that is neurotoxic. They present with nausea, vomiting, restlessness, fever, arrhythmias, and seizures.

Option B - Sea snake which is myotoxic. The main presentation is generalized rhabdomyolysis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Severe
    • Edema and necrosis
  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Mild
  • Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis

Saw scaled viper:

Green pit viper:

Common krait:

King cobra:

Sea snake:

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Rosenbach sign - Pulsations of the liver
Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen
Muller sign - Systolic pulsations of uvula

questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen. Traube's sign is a pistol shot sound heard over femoral arteries. 

Aortic regurgitation (AR). 

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other signs :

  • Pulsations of the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly are called Gerhardt’s sign. (Option B)
  • Rosenbach sign is seen in AR where pulsations are felt over the liver (Option A)
  • Becker's sign is the presence of retinal artery pulsation on fundoscopy. (Option C)
  • Systolic pulsations of uvula is known as Muller's sign. (Option D)

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

  • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
  • In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:
    • The patient is symptomatic
    • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
    • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text:
Identify the type of Mapleson’s circuit shown in the image below.

FG- Fresh gas

P- Patient
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mapleson’s Type B breathing circuit. There is the presence of a corrugated tube, and the fresh gas flow and valve are located near the patient.

Mapleson’s breathing systems are used for delivering oxygen and anesthetic agents and eliminating carbon dioxide during anesthesia. They consist of different components: Fresh gas flow, reservoir bag, breathing tubes, expiratory valve, and patient connection.

There are six types of Mapleson’s circuits denoted by A – F.

Other options:

Option A - In Mapleson type A circuits, the fresh gas flow enters through the opposite end of the circuit near the reservoir bag. They have a spring-loaded pop-off valve located near the patient. It is the most efficient for spontaneous ventilation.

Option C - Type C Mapleson circuits are similar to Type B circuits, but they do not have the corrugated tube.

Option D - Type D  circuits have fresh gas flow is near the patient end, and excess gas is vented off at the opposite end of the circuit. It is the most efficient for controlled ventilation.

 

Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: A radiology consultant advises you to use a water-soluble contrast media having an iodine particle ratio of 6:1 in a patient referred for a radiological investigation. Which of the following contrast media will you prefer?
questions.solution:
Non-ionic Dimers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 6:1

Contrast agents can be divided into water-soluble (iodine-containing) and non-water-soluble (barium) compounds.

Classification of iodinated contrast:

  • Ionic – Monomer and dimer
  • Non-ionic– Monomer and dimer

Other options:

  • Ionic monomers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 3:2
  • Ionic Dimers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 6:2 or 3:1
  • Non-ionic monomers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 3:1

Related Pearl: Classification of iodinated contrast medias:

  Iodinated contrast materials  
Types Ionic  Non-ionic
Subtypes  Monomer Dimer Monomer Dimer
Osmolarity

1400- 1600 mOsm (Not preferred due to high osmolarity)

 600- 800 mOsm 600- 800 mOsm 300 mOsm
Iodine: particle ratio 3:2 6:2 or 3:1 3:1 6:1
Examples 

Diatrizoate (Urograffin)

Iothalamate

Ioxaglate

Iohexol (most commonly used)

Ioversol

Iopamidol

Iodixanol

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department complaining of depression and loneliness. History taking reveals that he does not engage in any social activity because he’s afraid of being rejected. Identify the likely personality disorder in this patient:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, as the patient does not engage in social activities due to fear of being rejected.

Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection leading to socially withdrawn lives, low levels of energy, easy fatigability, lack of enthusiasm, and inability to enjoy life.

Other options:

Option B: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by unwarranted suspicion, hypersensi­tivity, jealousy, envy, rigidity, excessive self-importance, and a tendency to blame and ascribe evil motives to others.

 Option C: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by shyness, oversensitivity, seclusive­ ness, avoidance of close or competitive relationships, eccentric­ity, no loss of capacity to recognize reality, daydreaming, and an ability to express hostility and aggression.

 Option D: Antisocial personal­ity disorder covers persons in conflict with society. They are incapable of loyalty, selfish, callous, irresponsible, impulsive, and unable to feel guilt or learn from experience; they have low levels of frustration tolerance and a tendency to blame others.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: Which of the following lesions in tuberous sclerosis show hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands of immature hair follicles on histopathological examination?
questions.solution:
Angiofibromas show hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands of immature hair follicles on histopathological examination.

The characteristic findings of various lesions of tuberous sclerosis are as follows:

Ash leaf macules: They are ovoid or leaf-shaped hypopigmented macules. Histopathology will show abnormal melanocytes that have reduced tyrosinase activity. Electron microscopy would reveal defective melanization of melanosomes.

The following image shows an ash-leaf macule:

Periungual fibromas (Koenen’s tumor): They are smooth, firm, flesh-colored outgrowths emerging from the nail folds. These lesions classically have a distal part with loose collagen and many blood vessels and a larger proximal part composed of dense collagen bundles and fewer capillaries. The following image shows Koenen's tumor - 

Angiofibromas: they are red-brown, telangiectatic papules, commonly found in naso‐labial furrows to the cheeks and chin, and are occasionally found in the ears. They show hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands of immature hair follicles on histopathological examination. Angiofibromas were previously misnamed as adenoma sebaceum.

Shagreen patches: It is an irregularly thickened, elevated, skin-colored plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region. They show an excess of collagen and no other characteristic change. Hence, cannot be identified on the basis of histopathology alone as most other lesions also have an excess of collagen.

Other important features of tuberous sclerosis are multiple retinal nodular hamartomas, cortical tuber, subependymal nodule, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, etc.

questions.text: The given image depicts Brown-Sequard syndrome. The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion. Which of the following is inappropriately matched?
questions.solution:
The part marked 3 is incorrectly matched. Discriminative touch (also known as fine touch) is lost on the ipsilateral side of the lesion in Brown Sequard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features.

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration
  • Loss of discriminative touch
  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features

  • Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text:
With respect to the Lineweaver- Burk plot shown for a given enzyme and inhibitor, which of the following happens on increasing inhibitor concentration?

where, V is the reaction velocity and [S] is the substrate concentration.

choices.text: Decrease in binding affinity of substrate to enzyme
Decrease in the Km value of the enzyme
Decrease in the slope of red line
Decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second

questions.solution:
The red line in the graph represents a reaction with a noncompetitive inhibitor. Increasing inhibitor concentration will lead to a decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second.

In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds the enzyme other than the active site. It causes a change in the activity of enzymes, as a result of which reaction is not catalyzed. The total number of products hence formed are lesser. It however does not affect the affinity (represented by Km value) of the enzyme to bind the substrate.

This can be plotted on a graph. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors where v0 is the reaction velocity and [S] is the substrate concentration.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

On increasing the inhibitor concentration, the slope of the red line (1/V vs 1/S) increases, or in other words Vmax decreases.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: The test below depicts the presence of which of the following defects of the left eye?
questions.solution:
The test shown is the cover - uncover test. There is abduction of the eye with suspected deviation (left eye) on covering the fixing eye (right eye) which suggests left esotropia.

This test consists of two parts:

  • Cover test
  • Uncover test

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotropia (manifest squint). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate on a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotropia/Heterotropia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria
Adduction (Nasal recovery) Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward/Upward movement Vertical phoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery is noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

Related Pearl: Classification of Strabismus

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: A teenager comes to the emergency room with profuse bleeding from the nose. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which part of the septum is it located in?
questions.solution:
The Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area which is present at the anteroinferior part of the septum.

 

Bleeding from inside the nose is called epistaxis and often presents as an emergency. Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the site of epistaxis in 90% of the cases.

Four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called the Kiesselbach’s plexus. This area is exposed to the drying effect of inspiratory current and to fingernail trauma and is the usual site for epistaxis in children and young adults.

The four contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery, which supplies the nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Blood supply of the nose:

Nasal Septum:

  • Internal carotid system
    • Anterior ethmoidal artery - branch of ophthalmic artery
    • Posterior ethmoidal artery - branch of ophthalmic artery
  • External carotid system 
    • Nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches from the sphenopalatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Septal branch of greater palatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Septal branch of superior labial artery - branch of facial artery

Lateral wall

  • Internal carotid system
    • Anterior ethmoidal - branch of ophthalmic artery
    • Posterior ethmoidal - branch of ophthalmic artery
  • External carotid system
    • Posterior lateral nasal branches from the sphenopalatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Greater palatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Nasal branch of anterior superior dental artery - infraorbital branch of maxillary artery
    • Branches of facial artery to nasal vestibule

questions.text: A  45-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of increasing pain in his right hand over the past few months. On examination, there is a palpable lump over the thumb and an X-ray was done which is given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation at this age and the radiograph showing popcorn calcification are suggestive of chondrosarcoma.

Chondrosarcoma is the second most common nonhematological primary malignancy of the bone(Osteosarcoma is the commonest). It can be primary or secondary. Secondary chondrosarcomas develop at the site of a previously existing benign cartilage lesion.

Primary chondrosarcomas are commonly seen at 40-60 years of age whereas the age group for secondary chondrosarcoma is 25-45 years.

Clinical features:

  • Pelvis, proximal femur, and proximal humerus are the common locations.
  • The hand is a rare location. However, it is the most common primary bone malignancy in the hand.
  • Primary chondrosarcoma usually presents with increasing pain and a palpable lump.
  • Asymptomatic radiological abnormality is a common presentation in enchondromas but is not seen in chondrosarcomas.

Radiological findings:

  • It arises from the medullary cavity and shows irregular matrix calcification.
  • Characteristic calcification pattern is described as "popcorn", "punctate", or "comma-shaped"
  • Bone destruction, cortical erosion, and periosteal reaction may be seen.
  • CT or MRI is used to identify the presence of secondary chondrosarcomas.
  • Secondary chondrosarcoma is suspected of the cartilage cap of the lesion is more than 2 cm in a skeletally mature patient.

Conditions that can cause secondary chondrosarcoma includes:

  • Multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses.
  • Ollier disease(multiple enchondromas)
  • Maffucci syndrome(multiple enchondromas with soft-tissue hemangiomas).
  • Synovial chondromatosis
  • Periosteal chondroma
  • Chondroblastoma
  • Previous radiation treatment
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Chondromyxoid fibroma

Treatment:

  • Extended curettage with intraoperative adjuvant treatments is considered for low-grade lesions confined to the medullary canal.
  • Low-grade lesions with soft tissue extensions and high-grade lesions are managed with wide or radical resection or amputation.
  • Chemotherapy is not indicated for conventional chondrosarcoma but is used for mesenchymal or dedifferentiated variants.
  • Radiotherapy is only used as a palliative measure for surgically inaccessible tumors.

Other options:

Osteosarcoma:

It is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

Radiographic findings: The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a "Codman's triangle" or it may have a "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on X-ray.

Enchondroma is a benign lesion consisting of a lobulated mass of hyaline cartilage arising from the medullary canal. The most common site is the Metaphysis of small bones of the hand and feet. Pathologic fractures are common in this condition. Multiple enchondromas increase the incidence of sarcomatous degeneration as in Ollier disease. 

Below is an x-ray showing multiple enchondromatosis of the phalanges. 

Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor:

The commonly affected age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age
Simple bone cyst Proximal Humeral Metaphysis <20years
Enchondroma

Hand bones

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

4th & 5th

Decade

Osteochondroma

(Exostosis)

 Distal Femoral Metaphysis <18years
Osteoid osteoma Diaphysis of Femur

2nd & 3rd

decade
Osteoblastoma Posterior column of vertebra

2nd & 3rd

decade

Osteoclastoma (GCT)

 Distal femoral epiphysis

2nd -4th

Decade
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst Long bone Metaphysis <18years
Osteosarcoma Distal Femoral Metaphysis

BIMODAL

Primary- 2nd Decade Secondary-6th and 7th Decade
Ewings sarcoma Diaphysis of Femur 5-25 years
Chondrosarcoma Any site in the bone - mc in proximal femur 3rd-5th decade
Clear cell chondrosarcoma Proximal femoral epiphysis  3rd-5th decade
Adamantinoma Diaphysis of Tibia  20-40 years
 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

 

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance / Codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor, adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance / Shepherd's

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors (chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn, punctate or comma-shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Stippled or Punctate calcification

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors (osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment / Trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double-density fluid levels and intra-lesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign / Corduroy / Jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangioma

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are present in the plane marked as 1?
  1. Origin of the celiac trunk
  2. Origin of the portal vein
  3. Lower limit of the spinal cord in newborn
  4. Lower limit of the spinal cord in adults
  5. Origin of the superior mesenteric artery
questions.solution:
The structure marked "1" in the image is transpyloric plane that passes through the lower border of L1. The origin of the portal vein, the lower limit of the spinal cord in adults, and the origin of the superior mesenteric artery are present on this plane.

The transpyloric plane (Addison's plane) passes midway between the suprasternal notch of the manubrium and the upper border of the pubic symphysis. This approximately corresponds to midway between the xiphisternal joint and the umbilicus.

Posteriorly, this plane passes through the lower half of the body of the first lumbar vertebra (lower border of L1). 

Anteriorly, it intersects the costal margin at the ninth costal cartilage.

Structures present in the transpyloric plane:

Organs  Neurovascular structures 
Pylorus of stomach Origin of the superior mesenteric artery
Neck of the pancreas Origin of the renal artery
Duodenojejunal flexure Origin of the portal vein (behind the neck of the pancreas)
Fundus of the gallbladder Lower limit of the spinal cord in adults
Hilum of the left kidney (right kidney is slightly lower)  Cisterna chyli

 Other options:

  • The origin of the celiac trunk is at T12 level and
  • The lower limit of the spinal cord in newborn is at L3 level.

questions.text: Identify the following method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an E-test (epsilometer) which is a diffusion and dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.

It is a quantitative technique for determining antimicrobial susceptibility and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC).

  1. An absorbent strip containing a predefined gradient (serial dilution) of antibiotic concentration immobilized along its length is placed on a lawn inoculum of a bacterium.
  2. An elliptical zone of inhibition is produced surrounding the strip. 
  3. The antibiotic concentration at which the ellipse edge intersects the strip is taken as the MIC value.

The given image shows another E-test.

The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:

  1. Diffusion methods: 
    • Kirby–Bauer disk diffusion method
    • Stokes disk diffusion method
  2. Dilution methods: 
    • Broth dilution
    • Agar dilution
  3. Diffusion and dilution method:
    • E–test (Epsilometer)
  4. Automated methods:
    • VITEK 2 
    • Phoenix system 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method. 

To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface.

Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive)

The below image shows the Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method.

 

The below image shows Tube dilution method.

The below image shows Stokes method

questions.text: A 75-year-old man who is a known case of diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease visits the fever clinic with a history of high-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite for the past 5 days. He has been diagnosed with moderate COVID 19 disease. The monoclonal antibody bamlanivimab is administered. Which part of the virus is it directed against?
questions.solution:
The patient who is diagnosed with moderate COVID-19 disease in a non-hospitalised set-up with a high risk of progression (DM, CKD and ≥65 years of age) can be treated with bamlanivimab. It is directed against the Sars-CoV-2 Spike protein.

Bamlanivimab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the spike (S) surface protein of SARS-CoV-2, designed to block the virus’s attachment and entry into human cells. Possible side effects include anaphylaxis and infusion-related reactions, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, itching, and vomiting. Etesevumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the SARS-CoV-2 surface spike protein’s receptor binding domain.

Casirivimab and imdevimab consist of two antibodies that bind to different regions of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein receptor-binding domain.

Among ambulatory care patients, IDSA guidelines suggest the use of bamlanivimab/etesivimab in patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 who are at high risk for progression to severe disease. High-risk patients are those meeting at least one of the following criteria:  

  • Have a body mass index ≥35
  • Have chronic kidney disease
  • Have diabetes
  • Have immunosuppressive disease
  • Are currently receiving immunosuppressive treatment  
  • Are ≥65 years of age 
  • Are ≥55 years of age and have cardiovascular disease, or hypertension or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease/other chronic respiratory diseases  
  • Are 12–17 years of age and have BMI ≥85th percentile for their age and gender, or sickle cell disease, or congenital or acquired heart disease, or neurodevelopmental disorders, for example, cerebral palsy or asthma, reactive airway or other chronic respiratory diseases that requires daily medication for control

The following image shows the management algorithm:

The following image shows the structure of the virus:

NOTE:

FDA has recently expanded the emergency use authorization for the monoclonal antibody combination Bamlanivimab and Etesevimab. It can now be used for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID-19 and for post-exposure prophylaxis in all patients, including newborns who are at high risk for progression to severe COVID-19.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with left side hemiplegia, right side facial palsy and right side lateral rectus weakness. Which of the following will be the likely cause for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve) weakness and ipsilateral 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) palsy with contralateral hemiplegia are seen in ventral pontine syndrome/ Millard–Gubler syndrome.

CNS lesion   Effects
Millard–Gubler Syndrome/Ventral pontine syndrome
  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve weakness
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiplegia
Gradenigo’s Syndrome
  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy
  • Mastoiditis
  • Deafness, Ear pain
Foville’s Syndrome/ Dorsal pontine syndrome 
  • Lateral gaze palsy
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
Balint's syndrome
  • Optic ataxia
  • Ocular apraxia- difficulty in initiating voluntary eye movements
  • Visuospatial disorientation

Note:

In Millard-Gubler syndrome, there is a ventral pontine injury (lesion in abducens fascicle) that causes lateral rectus weakness. In Foville's syndrome, there is a dorsal pontine injury (lesion in the abducens nucleus) that causes lateral gaze palsy.

Abducens nucleus contains interneurons to the medial rectus subnucleus of the contralateral eye. Therefore, an abducens nuclear lesion produces a complete lateral gaze palsy from weakness of both the ipsilateral lateral rectus and the contralateral medial rectus.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her second trimester comes for a routine antenatal check-up. During ultrasound examination of the fetus, the radiologist notices fractures of the long bones. The fetal head is compressible by the ultrasound probe and the echogenicity of the cranium is low. Which subtype of this condition is suspected in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound findings of intrauterine fractures, compressible fetal head and low echogenicity of the cranium is suggestive of the type II variant of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It is uniformly fatal in utero or during the perinatal period.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Brittle bone disease) is caused by deficiencies in the synthesis of type I collagen. OI principally affects bone, but it also impacts other tissues rich in type I collagen (joints, eyes, ears, skin, and teeth). It is caused by mutations in genes encoding the α1 and α2 chains of type I collagen. These mutations result in misfolding of collagen polypeptides and defective assembly of higher-order collagen chains.

It can be separated into four major clinical subtypes that vary widely in severity. The severity of the disease is based on the location of the mutation within the protein.

Individuals with type I OI have a normal life span, but experience childhood fractures that decrease in frequency following puberty.

The type II variant, which is uniformly fatal in utero or during the perinatal period, is characterized by extraordinary bone fragility and multiple intrauterine fractures.

Major clinical features include: 

  • Death in utero or within days of birth
  • Skeletal deformity with excessive fragility and multiple fractures
  • Blue sclera

The prognosis is poor and lethal during the perinatal period.

The following image shows blue sclera that is commonly seen in osteogenesis imperfecta:

Related Pearl: Subtypes of Osteogenesis imperfecta

 

Subtypes

Clinical features

 Inheritance and Prognosis

Subtype I-

Decreased synthesis of pro-α1(1) chain

Abnormal pro-α1(1) or pro-α2(1) chains

 

Blue sclera

Normal stature

Skeletal fragility

Dentinogenesis imperfecta

Hearing impairment

Joint laxity

Inheritance- 

Autosomal dominant

 

Prognosis- 

Compatible with survival

Subtype II- 

Abnormally short pro-α1(1) chain Unstable triple helix Abnormal or insufficient pro-α2(1)

Death in utero or within days of birth

Skeletal deformity with excessive fragility and multiple fractures

Blue sclera

Inheritance- 

Most are autosomal recessive Few are autosomal dominant

 

Prognosis- 

Perinatal lethal

Subtype III-

Altered structure of pro-peptides of pro-α2(1)

Impaired formation of triple helix

 

Growth retardation

Multiple fractures

Progressive kyphoscoliosis

Blue sclera at birth that become white

Hearing impairment

Dentinogenesis imperfecta

Inheritance- 

Autosomal dominant (75%) Autosomal recessive (25%)

 

Prognosis- 

Progressive, deforming

 

Subtype IV-

Short pro-α2(1) chain Unstable triple helix

Postnatal fractures

normal sclerae

Moderate skeletal fragility

Short stature

Sometimes dentinogenesis imperfecta

Inheritance- 

Autosomal dominant

Prognosis- 

Compatible with survival

 

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: You are a part of the team spearheading a new experimental treatment modality for a rare type of cancer. When it is time for conducting human trials, ethical guidelines must be followed according to which of the following declarations?
questions.solution:
The Declaration of Helsinki gives a set of ethical principles directed to the medical community for human experimentation.

Other options :

Declaration Significance
Geneva

Physician’s dedication to the humanitarian goals of medicine. It is known as the modern Hippocratic oath.
Sydney

It describes about the determination of death and recovery of organs. It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasizing the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.
Istanbul It addresses the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal care clinic at 30 weeks of gestation. You are asked to perform a detailed physical examination on her and document the findings in the case sheet. Which of the following cardiovascular findings would be specific to a pathological cardiac condition, if documented?
questions.solution:
Grade 4 early diastolic murmur documented is specific to a pathologic cardiac condition in a pregnant female. Any diastolic murmur is never a part of the physiological change in pregnancy. 

Physiological changes in pregnancy

Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)

Clinical examination

  • Pulse rate: Increases
  • Pedal edema: although it can be a sign of cardiac disease, it is also a normal physiological change in pregnancy. (Option A)
  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • Diastolic BP: Decreases
  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • The heart is displaced upwards and to the left
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • S1 M increased and widely split
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • Occasional but prominent S3 at mitral area (Option D)
  • Murmurs
    • Ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal border. (Option B)
    • Continuous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)

ECG changes

  • Left axis deviation (due to elevation of the diaphragm)
  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement.
  • Mild ST changes in the inferior leads.
  • Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is a left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension 
  • Increased left ventricular mass

X-ray:

X-ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex).

Clinical indicators of heart disease during the pregnancy

Symptoms:

  • Progressive dyspnea or orthopnea
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Chest pain 

Clinical signs:

  • Cyanosis
  • Clubbing of fingers
  • Persistent neck vein distention
  • Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
  • Diastolic murmur
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Persistent tachycardia and/or arrhythmia
  • Persistently split S2
  • Fourth heart sound (S4)
  • Features of pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed for his gestational age. Which of the following is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score?
questions.solution:
The cubital angle is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded new Ballard score.

The expanded New Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn and thereby calculate the gestational age.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • The minimum score is -10 and the maximum score is 50.
  • It is accurate to within 2 wk of actual gestational age
  • Premature infants have low scores while post dated infants have higher scores.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Posture
  2. Square window (wrist)
  3. Arm recoil
  4. Popliteal angle
  5. Scarf sign
  6. Heel to ear

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Plantar surface
  4. Breast
  5. Eye/ear
  6. Genitals - male or female

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) only if its diameter is more than 55 mm in a male patient. 

If the diameter is less than 55 mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55 mm.

Indications for surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm:

  • Size >5.5 cm in males 
  • Size >5 cm in females 
  • Expansion of >1 cm in one year 
  • Painful tender aneurysm 
  • Thrombosed aneurysm; aneurysm with distal emboli

Management of aortic aneurysm: AAA is surgically managed by dacron graft repair. It can be either open or EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) 

  • Open surgical repair is done by exposing the aorta through a mid-sternal incision and graft replacement. To expose the aorta the descending colon should be mobilized medially and this is known as left visceral rotation or Mattox procedure.
  • EVAR is a minimally invasive procedure in which an aortic stent graft is placed on the nonaneurysmal aortoiliac segment.

Complications following an AAA repair are:

  • Cardiovascular (ischemia and infarction)
  • Respiratory (atelectasis or consolidation).
  • Colonic ischemia.
  • Renal failure.
  • Aortoduodenal fistula
  • spinal cord ischemia

The given image below shows the technique of EVAR:
